comments.author: SeeminglyScience
comments.body: PowerShell itself doesn't have any options for this, but it also doesn't really have a way to surface it.  You can use win32 API's (or I think sysinternals might have a tool for it?) to set something up like this yourself, but if you'd like the feature baked into conhost/terminal you'd want to file the issue on [microsoft/terminal](https://github.com/microsoft/terminal) or feedback hub/user voice.

comments.author: HumanEquivalentUnit
comments.body:
PowerShell doesn't control how it is displayed on screen, it has to be run inside a terminal program like PowerShell ISE, or Visual Studio Code, or the most basic one is Windows Console Host. It's up to them to be "always on top" or not, and I don't think any of them have that option.

If you are willing to try another terminal program, [ConEmu](https://conemu.github.io/) is a popular one which can run PowerShell and has [Always on top settings](https://conemu.github.io/en/SettingsAppearance.html).

comments.author: ghost
comments.body: ok. I'll try it. thank you.
